msContents.summary:
The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. According to the colophon, this beautifully illuminated manuscript was written with golden ink on indigo-dyed paper in1695 CE, during the shared reign of three kings,
Jitāmitramalla
(in the manuscript called Jitāmṛtamalla), Ugramalla and Bhūpatīndramalla (in the manuscript called Indrapratīndramalla). The manuscript was commissioned as an object of worship, probably by a group of Buddhist monks. The first one named is
Śrīdevamuni , who seemed to be the major donor; another monk named is Śrījñāna , from the Jetavanamahāvihāra in Bhaktapur (however according to Locke (1985: 462) this vihāra is situated in the village of Thimi near Bhaktapur). Even if commissioned by monks living in Bhaktapur, the manuscript has been written in Kathmandu (the then capital of an independent, separate kingdom).

supportDesc.condition: Complete, in good condition. Sometimes worm-eaten. The margins are slightly worn out. The writing is sometimes smudged, sometimes scratched.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 65 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: Two string holes, enclosed by double vertical frame lines.
layout.p: Triple marginal frame in silver and golden ink. Folio 1 verso and folio 2 recto are title pages in Tibetan style, in which the script is similar to the Lantsha script (i.e. the Tibetan adaptation of the Rañjanā script) written in a larger module (only 3 lines per page).

handNote.desc: First hand: Rañjanā in golden ink (main text, and some corrections).
Second hand: Nepālākṣarā in black and white ink (Corrections and retracing).

decoNote.desc:
The beginnings of the various dhāraṇis, as well as the colophon, are decorated with polichrome miniatures of approximately 5 cm in width, put in the centre of the page and exceeding the written area.
On f. 1v, representation of the Buddha in dharmacakramudrā
On f. 2r, representation of the goddess Pratisarā.
On f. 39v, representation of the Buddha in bhūmisparśamudrā
On f. 40r, representation of the goddess Sāhasrapramardanī.
On f. 77v, representation of the Buddha in dhyānamudrā
On f. 78r, representation of the goddess Māyūrī.
On f. 134v, representation of the Buddha in vitarkamudrā
On f. 135r, representation the goddess Śītavatī.
On f. 138v, representation of the Buddha in dhyānamudrā
On f. 139r, representation of the goddess Mantrānusāraṇī
On f. 146v, representation of a Buddhist deity (or maybe the king).
On f. 147r, representation of a Buddhist deity.

On the outer side of the front cover, traces of materials smeared on the manuscript during worship rites.
On a label attached to the cover, the note "Sotheby's London, 238" on one side, and "238, 30. Mar 1982" on the other side.

On the outer side of the back cover, a note in Devanāgarī written on a label paper glued to the cover: paṃcarakṣāsuvarṇakī • rājā sumatijayajitāmalladeva • rājā ugramalladeva • rājā bhupatiṃdramalladevasya vijayarājya saṃ° 815 sāka

history.provenance: Bought with library funds from Sotheby's, London, in 29 March 1982 for £ 230.85.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
